metadata.title: Cooperation of nitrogen-doping and catalysis to improve the Li-ion storage performance of lignin-based hard carbon

Cooperation of nitrogen-doping and catalysis to improve the Li-ion storage performance of lignin-based hard carbon Zhewei Yang Huajun Guo ⁎ Feifei Li Xinhai Li Zhixing Wang Lizhi Cui Jiexi Wang School of Metallurgy and Environment, Central South University, Changsha 410083, Hunan, China School of Metallurgy and Environment Central South University Changsha Hunan 410083 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Hard carbon draws great interests as anode material in lithium ion batteries (LIBs) due to its high theoretical capacity, high rate capability and abundance of its precursors. Herein we firstly synthesize the lignin-melamine resins by grafting melamine onto lignin. Afterwards, nitrogen doped hard carbon is prepared by the pyrolysis of lignin-melamine resins with the aid of catalyst (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) at 1000 °C. Compared with the samples without nitrogen-doping and catalysis, as-prepared nitrogen doped hard carbon exhibits higher reversible capacity (345 mAh g–1 at 0.1 A g−1), higher rate capability (145 mAh g−1 at 5 A g–1) and excellent cycling stability. The superior electrochemical performance is ascribed to the synergistic effect of nitrogen doping, graphitic structure and amorphous structure. Among them, nitrogen doping could create the vacancies around the nitrogen sites, which enhance the reactivity and the electronic conductivity of materials. Additionally, graphitic structure also enhances the electronic conductivity of materials, thus improving the electrochemical performance of hard carbon. It is worthwhile that lignin, renewable and abundant biopolymer, is converted to hard carbon with good electrochemical performance, which realizes the high value utilization of lignin. Graphical abstract The superior Li-ion storage performance of lignin-based hard carbon is ascribed to the synergistic effect of nitrogen doping, graphitic structure and amorphous structure. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Hard carbon Lignin Melamine Nitrogen-doping Catalysis 1 Introduction Nowadays, facing the challenges of ecological environmental pollution and natural resources’ shortage, it is urgent for all industry to pursue “green” or sustainable development [1–6]. In the field of energy conversion and storage, lithium ion batteries (LIBs) are considered to be the most efficient energy storage devices for electric vehicles, which call for high energy density, high power density and long cycling life [7–9]. Various carbon materials have been investigated as anode materials for LIBs, including graphite, soft carbon and hard carbon [10,11]. Among them, hard carbon draws great interests as anode material due to its high theoretical capacities, high rate capability and abundance of its precursors [12–15]. The intrinsically disordered microarchitecture of hard carbon is in favour of the insertion, adsorption and transmission of lithium ion. However, hard carbon prepared at low temperature has much structure defects and a low conductivity, which goes against its electrochemical performance. Nitrogen-doping is an effective approach to improve the electrochemical performance for the carbon-based anode [16–19]. The presence of N heteroatoms can generate extrinsic defects and greatly enhance the ion and electron diffusion of the carbon-based materials. For example, Huang prepared the N-doped porous carbon fibers derived from polypyrrole as anodes in LIBs, which exhibited capacity as high as 1200 mAh g−1, superior rate capability and cyclic stability [17]. Additionally, catalytic action is able to introduce the graphitic structure within carbonaceous material, which is also conducive to its electronic conductivity, thus enhancing the electrochemical performance [20,21]. To date, different materials have been served as precursors for hard carbon, such as pitch [22], phenol formaldehyde resin [23] and biomass [24]. Lignin, as the second most abundant biopolymer in nature after cellulose, is one kind of attractive carbon precursor because of abundance, carbon rich, low cost and renewable. In addition, lignin is main by-product treated as a waste in pulp and paper industry, which pollutes the environment and the soil. Therefore, it is of great significance to convert lignin or lignin derivatives to high value added products [25–27]. Herein, lignin-melamine resins as the precursors containing N heteroatoms are firstly synthesized by grafting melamine onto lignin. Afterwards, nitrogen doped hard carbon is prepared by the pyrolysis of lignin-melamine resins with the aid of catalyst (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O). The structure and electrochemical performance are characterized and the relationship between them is also discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials synthesis Lignin was purchased from Yanghai environmental materials company (Shandong, China). The lignin-melamine resins were synthesized using lignin, melamine and formaldehyde solution as ingredients. 2 g of lignin were dispersed into 50 mL ammonia aqueous solution (pH = 9∼10, Solution A). Then, 0.5 g melamine and 5 mL formaldehyde solution were dissolved in 10 mL of distilled water (Solution B). Next, solution B was added into solution A with continually stirring at 90 °C for 4 h. The mixture solution was cooled down to room temperature. Then the pH of solution was adjusted to the required value (pH = 1∼2) by adding 1 M hydrochloric acid (HCl) solution to precipitate lignin-melamine resins. Finally, the lignin-melamine resins were collected after centrifugation, drying and thermocompression. Afterwards, the lignin-melamine resins as precursors were carbonized and catalyzed at 1000 °C with the help of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O. Specifically, the precursors were impregnated with Ni(NO3)2 solution for 12 h. The mass ratio of Ni to precursor was kept at 3/10. After stirring in oil bath, the dry mixture was removed to a crucible and then sintered under argon atmosphere at 1000 °C for 4 h (heating/cooling rate: 3 °C min−1). At last, the obtained materials were dipped into 1 M HCl for 12 h to remove the nickel residual in matrix, followed by filtering and drying. The resulting lignin-melamine resin based hard carbon was named as CLM-Ni. For comparison, lignin and lignin-melamine resins were carbonized at 1000 °C without catalyst and prepared samples were named as CL and CLM, respectively. 2.2 Materials characterization FTIR was carried out on Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (Nicolet 6700). The microstructure was characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G12, 200 kV). X-ray diffraction patterns were obtained on Rigaku Rint-2000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on VG Multilab 2000. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms at 77.3 K were obtained using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and porosity analyzer. The specific surface area (SSA) was calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation. The pore size distribution (PSD) was analyzed using the BJH model. The electronic conductivities of all samples were tested using ST-2722 semiconductor resistivity of the powder tester by four-point probe method. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements The working electrodes were prepared by coating a mixture of as-prepared material with Super P conductive agent and poly (vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) binder in a weight ratio 8:1:1 dissolved in N-methyl pyrrolidinone (NMP) on copper foil. Then the electrodes were dried at 120 °C for 6 h and punched into disks in diameter of 12 mm. The electrochemical performance was tested in CR2025 coin cells with Li metal as the counter electrode. The mixture solution of 1 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate (EC), ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) (1/1/1, v/v/v) served as electrolyte. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) was tested using CHI1000C multi-channel potentiostat. Galvanostatic chargingdischarging (GCD) was carried out using a Neware GCD system. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was tested by a CHI 660A electrochemical workstation in the frequency range of 10−2∼105 Hz. All electrochemical measurements were operated at room temperature. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structure Lignin-melamine resins were firstly synthesized by grafting melamine onto lignin and the synthesis mechanism of lignin-melamine resins is shown in Scheme 1 . In order to graft melamine onto lignin, melamine was treated by carboxymethylation process firstly with the aid of formaldehyde. Then the condensation polymerization between carboxymethylated melamine and lignin occurred to form lignin-melamine resins. The FTIR spectra of lignin and lignin-melamine resin are shown in Fig. 1 (a). For lignin, the peaks at 1332 cm−1 and 1120 cm−1 are attributed to the C–O and C–H stretching vibration of syringyl lignin, respectively. The successful incorporation of melamine into lignin is demonstrated by the characteristic peaks at 1558 cm−1, 1352 cm−1 and 814 cm−1, which present the aromatic C–N stretching, ‘‘breathing’’ modes and deformation vibration in the triazine unit, respectively [28]. Additionally, the result is also demonstrated by the XPS analysis as shown in Fig. S1. N 1 s spectra could be fitted into two peaks corresponding to the neutral imine nitrogen atoms (CNHC) at 398.4 eV and triazine nitrogen atoms (C = NC) at 399.6 eV, respectively. The nitrogen content is as high as 31%. The XRD patterns of CL, CLM and CLM-Ni are displayed in Fig. 1(b). CL and CLM show two steamed bread peaks at ∼23° and ∼43° corresponding to the 002 and 100 planes, respectively, which indicate the amorphous structure [29]. However, CLM-Ni presents a relative sharp peak at 26.12° indicative of the formation of graphitic structure. The average graphene interlayer spacing (d 002) is 0.341 nm calculated by the Bragg's Law, which is larger than that of graphite (0.335 nm). In addition, the characteristic peaks of metallic nickel (JCPDS 89-7128) at 44.47°, 51.87° and 76.51° were observed after dipping and washing by HCl solution adequately. The SEM, TEM and HRTEM images of CLM and CLM-Ni are presented in Fig. 2 . CLM shows irregular particles with smooth surface as shown in Fig. 2(a). Additionally, the worm-like nanocarbon observed in HRTEM (Fig. 2d) reveals the amorphous structure. Nevertheless, the surface of LCM-Ni particles becomes rough and fluffy due to complex catalytic action as shown in Fig. 2(b). From the TEM (Fig. 2e) image, much nanocapsules and gauze-like nanosheets are observed. And the HRTEM image of LCM-Ni (Fig. 2f) reveals the graphitic structure embedded in amorphous carbon. The formation of graphitic structure was owing to the mechanisms of catalytic graphitization involving in the dissolution of amorphous carbon into catalyst particles followed by the precipitation of graphitic carbon [30,31]. Specifically speaking, the nickel nitrate in composite was firstly decomposed into corresponding nickel oxides at ∼300 °C. Secondly, the carbon reduced nickel oxides into metallic nickel during heating process. Finally, nickel oxides and metallic nickel in carbon matrix as catalyst help to convert the amorphous carbon into the order carbon. After dipping and washing adequately by HCl solution, trace amounts of metallic nickel embedded in matrix are retained. The obtained results from HRTEM images agree well with the XRD analysis. Fig. 3 (a,b) and Table 1 offer the detail textural characters of as-prepared samples. CLM-Ni possesses a specific surface area of 79.2 m2 g−1, which is higher than CLM (36.1 m2 g−1) and CL (14.6 m2 g−1). Type IV isotherms and pronounced hysteresis loops corresponding to the capillary condensation of CLM-Ni could be seen in Fig. 3(a), which indicates the existence of mesopores. The pore size center is located at 3.7 nm and average pore size is 10.9 nm for CLM-Ni, which are larger than CLM (pore size center of ∼2 nm and average pore size of 3.2 nm). It is proved that the SSA and pore size of CLM-Ni are increased after catalytic process. The mespores are formed because of the dissolution of metallic nickel and the complex carbonation process. XPS was used to investigate the elemental composition of CL, CLM and CLM-Ni. As shown in wide scan XPS spectra (Fig. 3c), the main components of all samples are carbon (C 1 s at ∼285 eV) and oxygen (O 1 s at ∼533 eV). As for CLM and CLM-Ni, additionally, the weak N 1 s peak at ∼400 eV is found indicating the successful incorporation of melamine into lignin indirectly. The nitrogen contents in CLM and CLM-Ni are 2% and 1.4%, respectively. As for CLM-Ni, the high-resolution N 1 s spectra (Fig. 3d) could be fitted into three major components corresponding to pyridinic nitrogen at 398.7 eV, pyrrolic nitrogen at 401.1 eV and graphitic nitrogen at 402.8 eV, respectively [32,33]. It is reported that N heteroatoms within carbonaceous material is able to create the vacancies and dangling bonds around the nitrogen sites, which enhance the reactivity and the electronic conductivity, thus improving the electrochemical performance of carbonaceous material [19]. In addition, metallic nickel (0.21 wt%) was also observed. The electronic conductivities of all samples were tested by four-point probe method. As shown in Table 1, CLM-Ni possesses higher electronic conductivity (909 S m−1) than CL (240 S m−1) and CLM (345 S m−1). 3.2 Electrochemical performance The CV curves of CLM-Ni and CLM tested at the scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 are shown in Fig. 4 (a) and inset, respectively. Both of CLM-Ni and CLM display the large irreversible peak at ∼0.7 V during the first cathodic scan, which is related to the formation of the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film due to the decomposition of electrolyte protecting electrolyte from continuous decomposition during subsequent cycling [34]. Compared with CLM (inset), CLM-Ni presents relative sharp redox peaks at 0.01∼0.15 V, which is ascribed to the formation of different graphite intercalation compounds (GIC) in the process of charging and discharging. The GCD curve of CLM-Ni during the initial three cycles at 0.1 A g−1 is displayed in Fig. 4(b). CLM-Ni presents the sloping profile and the voltage hysteresis phenomenon corresponding to the characteristic of hard carbon. CLM-Ni exhibits the initial charge capacity of 345 mAh g−1 and the low initial coulombic efficiency of 50% caused by large specific surface area. The GCD curves of CL, CLM and CLM-Ni at 0.1 A g−1 for the fifth cycle are shown in Fig. 4(c). CLM presents higher reversible capacity (338 mAh g−1) than that of CL (259 mAh g−1), which domesticates that nitrogen doping helps to improve capacity due to the enhancement of electrochemical reactivity. CLM and CLM-Ni possess almost capacities according to the inset of Fig. 4(c). However, the charge plateau capacity of CLM-Ni below 0.2 V is 85 mAh g−1, which is higher than that of CLM (71 mAh g−1) due to the formation of graphic structure. The rate capabilities of CL, CLM and CLM-Ni at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2 and 5 A g−1 are presented in Fig. 4(d). At 0.1 A g−1, the charge specific capacities of CL, CLM and CLM-Ni are 259, 338 and 321 mAh g−1, respectively. With the rise of current density, the specific capacity decreases. At 1 A g−1, CLM-Ni exhibits capacity retention of 69% with respect to initial specific capacity at 0.1 A g−1, which is higher than that of CLM (55%) and CL (42%). Even at 5 A g−1, CLM-Ni exhibits the capacity retention of 42%. CLM-Ni displays much better rate capability due to the cooperation of nitrogen-doping and catalysis. Graphitic nitrogen and pyridine nitrogen in carbon matrix are positively charged, which make for electrons transferring through the carbon, improving the electrochemical performance at high rates [35]. Additionally, the graphitic structure generated by catalysis could also improve the electrical conductivity of hard carbon. The conclusion could also be confirmed by EIS analysis. The Nyquist plots of three samples are shown in Fig. 4(e), which consist of two semicircles at high frequency and a linear slope at low frequency corresponding to the surface film resistance (R f) at high frequency, the charge transfer resistance (R ct) at medium frequency and the Warburg resistance (W o) at low frequency. In addition, the intercept along X-axis indicates the electrolyte resistance (R s) [36]. The plots are fitted with the aid of an appropriate electric equivalent circuit as shown in the inset of Fig. 4(e) and the fitting parameter values of three samples are presented in Table S1. Three samples have relative low R s ( < 5 Ω). CLM-Ni has lower R f (35 Ω) and R ct (18 Ω) than those of CLM (R f: 43 Ω; R ct: 33 Ω) and CL (R f: 67 Ω; R ct: 86 Ω). CLM-Ni possesses the lowest R ct indicating the highest rate capability among as-prepared samples. Compared with the electrochemical performances of some biomass derived hard carbons reported in literatures as shown in Table S2, CLM-Ni also displays much better rate capability [12,26,37–39]. The cycling stability of CL, CLM and CLM-Ni at 0.5 A g−1 after initial cycling for 5 cycles at 0.1 A g−1 is exhibited in Fig. 4(f). Three samples display favourable cycling stability. The charge specific capacity of CLM-Ni could retain 248 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles. In a word, superior electrochemical performance for CLM-Ni is attributed to the synergistic effect of nitrogen doping, graphitic structure and amorphous structure. Among them, nitrogen-doping could not only generate extrinsic defects in favour of Li storage and consequently improve the reversible capacity, but also improve the electrical conductivity of lignin based hard carbon. The graphitic structure formed during catalytic process also enhances the electrical conductivity which is conducive to the rate capability. 4 Conclusions In summary, the melamine is successfully grafted onto lignin and nitrogen doped hard carbon (CLM-Ni) is prepared by the pyrolysis of lignin-melamine resins with the aid of catalyst at 1000 °C. The nitrogen content in CLM-Ni is 1.4% by XPS analysis. Additionally, XRD and TEM analysis demonstrated that graphitic structure and amorphous structure are coexisted in CLM-Ni. CLM-Ni presents high reversible capacity (345 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1), high rate capability (145 mAh g−1 at 5 A g−1) and excellent cycling stability. The favourable electrochemical performance is attributed to the synergistic effect of nitrogen doping, graphitic structure and amorphous structure. More importantly, lignin, the renewable and abundant biopolymer, is converted to hard carbon with good electrochemical performance, which realizes the high value utilization of lignin. coredata.dc:description: Hard carbon draws great interests as anode material in lithium ion batteries (LIBs) due to its high theoretical capacity, high rate capability and abundance of its precursors. Herein we firstly synthesize the lignin-melamine resins by grafting melamine onto lignin. Afterwards, nitrogen doped hard carbon is prepared by the pyrolysis of lignin-melamine resins with the aid of catalyst (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) at 1000 °C. Compared with the samples without nitrogen-doping and catalysis, as-prepared nitrogen doped hard carbon exhibits higher reversible capacity (345 mAh g–1 at 0.1 A g−1), higher rate capability (145 mAh g−1 at 5 A g–1) and excellent cycling stability. The superior electrochemical performance is ascribed to the synergistic effect of nitrogen doping, graphitic structure and amorphous structure. Among them, nitrogen doping could create the vacancies around the nitrogen sites, which enhance the reactivity and the electronic conductivity of materials. Additionally, graphitic structure also enhances the electronic conductivity of materials, thus improving the electrochemical performance of hard carbon. It is worthwhile that lignin, renewable and abundant biopolymer, is converted to hard carbon with good electrochemical performance, which realizes the high value utilization of lignin.

coredata.dc:title: Cooperation of nitrogen-doping and catalysis to improve the Li-ion storage performance of lignin-based hard carbon
